data.name: HTML

samples.name: HTML
samples.description: With the HTML controls you can easily embed any kind of HTML content into your UI5 mobile application.

samples.name: Static HTML Provided as a String
samples.description: This is the simple use case for the HTML control: Some - usually decorative - HTML fragment is specified as a string and set to the content property. Without further configuration, the HTML control will convert this string to DOM nodes whenever it has to render.

samples.name: Static HTML Provided With Preserved DOM
samples.description: The second use case is similar to the first one: The HTML fragment is specified as a string. The difference is that after the first rendering, the HTML control tries to preserve the created DOM nodes as long as possible. Before each re-rendering step, the existing DOM is preserved in some hidden page area, and then the control and its relatives (parents, siblings) are rendered - this creates a new DOM node hierarchy. After the rendering, the preserved DOM content of the controls is integrated in the newly created DOM tree.

data.name: ComboBox

samples.name: Combo box
samples.description: The combo box control provides a list box with items and a text field allowing the user to either type a value directly into the control or choose from the list of existing items.

samples.name: Combo box - Two columns layout
samples.description: Use the combo box dropdown list with two columns layout if you need to display additional information to your options, like e.g. currencies to countries or abbreviations to systems.

samples.name: Combo box - Lazy loading
samples.description: Use this feature to defer initialization of items until the point at which the items are needed. It can improve performance, reduce memory usage and unnecessary client/server round-trips.

samples.name: Combo box - Search in both columns
samples.description: Combo box dropdown list with search functionality which checks both columns. When you need to display additional information on your options, like e.g. keys of countries or system abbreviations, and want to search in those as well.

samples.name: Combo box - Default Filtering
samples.description: The default filtering is 'starts with per term', which filters by the beginning of every word in every column. Autocomplete (type-ahead) works only for the first column, the leading value.

samples.name: Combo box - Custom filtering "Contains"
samples.description: You can override the default filtering "Starts with per term" with your own filter function using the setFilterFunction method. The "Contains" approach searches everywhere in the entries.

samples.name: Combo box - Custom filtering "Starts with"
samples.description: You can override the default filtering "Starts with per term" with your own filter function using the setFilterFunction method. The "Starts with" approach searches only in the beginning of the entries in both columns.

samples.name: ComboBox - Grouping of items
samples.description: Items in the ComboBox could be grouped by a property

samples.name: ComboBox - Validation
samples.description: The combo box control could be restricted to allow selection only from the items in the list.

data.name: Input

samples.name: Input - Assisted
samples.description: Assisted input is available via suggestions - shown as you type - and a value help dialog.

samples.name: Input - Assisted Two Values
samples.description: This example shows how to easily implement an assisted input with two-value suggestions.

samples.name: Input - Assisted Tabular Suggestions
samples.description: In this example assisted input is provided with table-like suggestions where several columns can display more details.

samples.name: Input - Checked
samples.description: Input checks are handled via the validation of the data binding. In this example there are two inputs that are validated (a) while the user types and (b) when the user continues the process. If the built-in validation types are not sufficient you can create your own, like the email type in this example.

samples.name: Input - Description
samples.description: This sample illustrates the usage of the description with input fields, e.g. description for units of measurements and currencies.

samples.name: Input - Password
samples.description: To make sure the password is not shown as clear text you set the 'type' of an input control to 'Password'.

samples.name: Input - Suggestions - Custom
samples.description: The default filtering for the suggestionItems aggregation uses a 'begins with' style operator. You can override this with your own custom filter function using the Input control's setFilterFunction method.

samples.name: Input - Suggestions - Dynamic
samples.description: With the Input control's suggest event, you can handle the suggestionItems yourself dynamically. This is useful when you have a server-side source of possible entries, and want to retrieve a specific subset by setting a filter on the aggregation binding with the model.

samples.name: Input - Suggestions - OSP
samples.description: If you need to use an Open Search Provider (OSP) to supply possible values, you can do this with the Input control's suggest event, and build the suggestionItems dynamically according to the results of the Open Search call.

samples.name: Input - Types
samples.description: Input type corresponds to the type attribute of the HTML input tag. On touch devices, it controls the keyboard layout. On desktop, the effect of this setting is browser dependent.

samples.name: Input - States
samples.description: This example demonstrates the different input field states, e.g. disabled, editable, with value help and value help only.

samples.name: Input - Value States
samples.description: This example shows different input value states.

samples.name: Input - Value Update
samples.description: Since 1.24 the value property of sap.m.Input is not updated on every keystroke, but first when the user presses Enter or leaves the input. The change was necessary to fully support the standard UI5 data binding with formatters and types. If you still need immediate update you have 2 options: Handle liveChange events or enable the boolean property valueLiveUpdate.

samples.name: Input - Key and Value
samples.description: This sample illustrates how the Input works with key and value values, when the data is available via list of suggestions.

samples.name: Input - Key and Value Tabular Suggestions
samples.description: This sample illustrates how the Input works with key and value values, when the data is provided with table-like suggestions.

samples.name: Input - Grouping of items
samples.description: Items in the Input could be grouped by a property

data.name: List

samples.name: List - Counter Indication
samples.description: The counter of an item quickly shows how many detail entries are related, without having to navigate to the detail page.

samples.name: List - Deletion
samples.description: Setting 'Delete' mode on a List means you can trigger the deletion of single items with a single press. The application has to decide if an additional confirmation is required.

samples.name: List - Footer
samples.description: With the 'footerText' property you can set a message that is shown at the very end of the list.

samples.name: List - Grouping & Context Menu
samples.description: Grouping your items makes it easier for the user to browse and find the desired content. This example also shows the context menu for the items in the List control.

samples.name: List - Growing
samples.description: The Growing feature helps if your content is too big to be loaded/shown at once. It paginates the content into smaller chunks - aka pages - which are loaded/shown one after another. Random access to pages (e.g jumping to the end) is not possible. Depending on the model the content is loaded on demand (OData) or shown on demand (JSON).

samples.name: List - Growing Upwards
samples.description: The Upwards Growing

samples.name: List - Items Type
samples.description: You can use the type property of any list item, which inherits from ListItemBase control, to demonstrate all possible types (see sap.m.ListType). In this example, you can see the Standard List Item behavior when different values of type property are selected.

samples.name: List - Loading Indication
samples.description: You can use enableBusyIndicator property to display loading animation while the data is being loaded from server. By default, this property is true and busy indicator will be shown after 1000ms. This behavior can be customized by setting the busyIndicatorDelay property. When this property is set to false, items stay on the List until data loading is completed.

samples.name: List - Navigation Indication
samples.description: If only a subset of the list items are navigable you should indicate those by setting their 'type' to 'Navigation'. This displays an navigation arrow. Do not show arrows if all items are navigable. This achieved by setting the 'type' to 'Active'.

samples.name: List - No Data Indication
samples.description: If the list is empty it indicates this state by displaying a message text.

samples.name: List - Selection
samples.description: 'Single selection' forces the user to choose exactly one out of many items. With the 'multi' selection the user can pick multiple items at the same time. This is helpful for e.g. batch processing. With 'includeItem' the selection is also changed when pressing the item.

samples.name: List - Selection & Search
samples.description: When searching a list with multi selection the previously selected items will stay selected. This is managed by the list control for you.

samples.name: List - Swipe
samples.description: With a swipe gesture you can show additional content for an item without having to navigate to a detail page. This feature is only available for touch devices.

samples.name: List - Header & Info Toolbar
samples.description: The 'headerText' property is an easy but limited way of setting the list header. If you need more flexibility you should assemble your own header or info toolbar that can also contain buttons. This example also demonstrates the sticky header toolbar and info toolbar options.

samples.name: List - Unread Indication
samples.description: With the Unread Indicator you can highlight new items making it easier for the user to discover them.

data.name: Page

samples.name: Page,Toolbar and Bar
samples.description: Each screen of a mobile application is typically represented by a 'Page' consisting of a header, a scrollable content area and optionally a footer. The standard header offers a navigation button and a title. Alternatively you can provide a customer header. Gernerally you should use Toolbars in the Page. If you need a centered title you may use a Bar.

samples.name: Fiori Object Page - Standard Classes
samples.description: This page implements the same sample as in 'Fiori Sample Page - sapUiFioriObjectPage' using standard margin classes. In contrast to using 'sapUiFioriObjectPage', the margins used for form, list, table and panel are responsive: they adapt to the available screen width. For more information, please search for 'Standard Margins' and take a look at our samples.

samples.name: Flexible sizing - Icon Tab Bar
samples.description: This page shows flexible sizing with an Icon Tab Bar: The upper part extends with its content, but doesn't react to viewport changes. The Icon Tab Bar reacts to the viewport size. The table inside takes the available space. If the minimum size of the table is reached, the page begins to scroll.

samples.name: Flexible sizing - Toolbar
samples.description: This page shows flexible sizing with a Toolbar. The upper part extends with its content, but doesn't react to viewport changes. The lower part reacts to the viewport size. The table inside takes the available space. If the minimum size of the table is reached, the page begins to scroll.

samples.name: Page Floating Footer
samples.description: The floating Footer allows the user to see the underlying content.

data.name: Planning Calendar

samples.name: simple Planning Calendar
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with single row selection that illustrates the built-in views.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - multiple selection
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with multiple row selection. No interval headers are displayed. On click on an interval a new appointment is created.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - without row header
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with only one row without row header.  On click on an interval a new appointment is created.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - with custom views
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with custom views to set number of hours, days and months and change view description. It illustrates both built-in and custom views. Sub-intervals are shown. Custom non-working days and hours are set. In months view some appointments are grouped. The group appointment mode can be toggled to expand the appointments.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - with one line appointments
samples.description: PlanningCalendar showing appointment with only title in one line to save space. The interval headers are only shown if there are some assigned in the visible area.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - with min. and max. date
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with min. date 2000-01-01 and max. date 2050-12-31

samples.name: Planning Calendar - with appointments modification
samples.description: PlanningCalendar containing sap.m.Popover with information for the appointments and sap.m.Dialog for creating a new appointment. Note: Illustrates how the PlanningCalendar can be used in combination with the sap.m.Popover and sap.m.Dialog controls for details/create. These features are NOT part of the control.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - with legend
samples.description: PlanningCalendar inside the main part of a sap.ui.layout.DynamicSideContent and a sap.m.PlanningCalendarLegend inside the side part. The legend includes calendar and appointments sections. For each sap.m.PlanningCalendarRow in the sap.m.PlanningCalendar some specific special dates of type non-working are set.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - Drag and Drop
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with draggable appointments. The sample represents three possible roles. If you are logged as an Admin, you can move appointments both within the same row and between different rows without any restrictions. As a Manager, you have the same rights as the Admin but appointments can be dropped only on free slots (no overlapping). As a team member you can only move the appointments within your own row. By pressing Ctrl/Cmd while dragging, the dropped appointment will copy the initial one.

samples.name: Planning Calendar - with header that remains visible (fixed on top) on scroll
samples.description: PlanningCalendar with header area that remains visible (fixed on top) when the rest of the content is scrolled out of view.

data.name: Responsive Table

samples.name: Table - Columns
samples.description: The table shares many features with the list and, in addition, introduces columns. The table is fully responsive and can hide columns or shown them in-place if the screen space is not sufficient. This example also demonstrates the different table pop-in layout options along with sticky column headers, header toolbar and info toolbar options.

samples.name: Table - Defining Column Width
samples.description: While defining the column width you can use percent values but you should be careful with them. Click to see some traps and tipps.

samples.name: Table - Breadcrumb
samples.description: With an InfoToolbar and some crumb logic you can navigate simple hierarchies with a breadcrumb table approach.

samples.name: Table - Fixed vs Auto Layout
samples.description:
You can use fixedLayout property to define the layout algorithm to be used for the table cells, rows, and columns.
When fixedLayout property is set to false, the width of the table and its cells depends on the content thereof. The column width is set by the widest unbreakable content in the cells.
By default, table is rendered with fixed layout algorithm. This means the horizontal layout only depends on the table's width and the width of the columns, not the contents of the cells. Cells in subsequent rows do not affect column widths.

samples.name: Table - Merge Cells
samples.description:
With column duplicate merging, you can improve the display of repeated data. See the effect of mergeDuplicates on the Supplier column, space permitting.
Note: This feature is ignored if a column is shown in the pop-in.

samples.name: Table - Personalization
samples.description: The Table Perso Dialog is a simple dialog to be used for allowing the user to set table personalizations, specifically column visibility and order. Use the Table Perso Controller in conjunction with a persistence service based on the abstract Table Perso Provider to have changes made and persisted.

samples.name: Table - Vertical Alignment
samples.description: This is a good example of how to vertically align different elements within a Table's ColumnListItem row template.

samples.name: Table - View Settings & Context Menu
samples.description: The View Settings Dialog is standard UI pattern for specifying sorting, grouping and filtering. For a table it should be triggered by a button in the table header with the 'drop-down-list' icon. The active filter should be shown with the table's info bar. This example also shows the context menu for the items in the Table control.

samples.name: Table - Export
samples.description: The table control provides export capabilities for downloading your data as a csv file. However, for huge tables, it is recommended that you provide an export mechanism on the server side.

samples.name: Table - Outdated Data
samples.description: You can use the 'showOverlay' property to indicate that the table data is no longer up to date. When the user modifies the filter values of the table, this results in displaying an overlay, which disables operations on the table. Once the user chooses 'Search', the filter values and table data are synchronized again and the overlay is removed.

samples.name: Table - Editable
samples.description: Table with edit/display togglable scenario.

samples.name: Table - Alternate Row Colors
samples.description: Table with alternating light and dark background colors. Note: The effect of this feature is only visible in the SAP Belize and Belize Deep themes.

samples.name: Table - Drag and Drop
samples.description: Shows the different kinds of drag-and-drop capabilities across view boundaries along with custom context menu alternatives to perform these action.

samples.name: Table - ContextualWidth (Dynamic)
samples.description: This example shows the container-based pop-in behavior. The container has dynamic width.

samples.name: Table - ContextualWidth (Static)
samples.description: This example shows the container-based pop-in behavior. The container has static width.

data.name: Text Area

samples.name: Text Area
samples.description: The Text Area allows to enter multi-line text and automatically breaks to a new line for overflow text. If the text gets too big to be displayed at once the user can scroll up and down.

samples.name: TextArea with MaxLength = true
samples.description: Shows the behavior of the control with the new showExceededText property (since 1.48) and maxLength = true

samples.name: TextArea - Value Update
samples.description: Since 1.30 the value property of sap.m.TextArea is not updated on every keystroke, but first when the user presses Enter or leaves the input. The change was necessary to fully support the standard UI5 data binding with formatters and types. If you still need immediate update you have 2 options: Handle liveChange events or enable the boolean property valueLiveUpdate.

samples.name: TextArea - Growing
samples.description: Since 1.38 the growing property of sap.m.TextArea gives the ability of a control to automatically grow and shrink dynamically with its content.

data.name: Standard Margins

samples.name: Margins All Around
samples.description: Use standard margin classes 'sapUiTinyMargin', 'sapUiSmallMargin', 'sapUiMediumMargin' or 'sapUiLargeMargin' to add a 8px (0.5rem), 16px (1rem), 32px (2rem) or 48px (3rem) margin to your control. This will clear the area all around your control (outside its border).

samples.name: Single-Sided Margins
samples.description: Clear the space to the left, right, top or bottom of your control. Choose a size ('Tiny', 'Small', 'Medium' or 'Large', which stands for 8px (0.5rem), 16px (1rem), 32px (2rem) or 48px (3rem) respectively) and a direction ('Begin', 'End', 'Top' or 'Bottom', where 'Begin' is left and 'End' is right and vice versa in right-to-left mode). If you would like to clear a 32px space to the left (resp. right in rtl mode), you would add class 'sapUiMediumMarginBegin'. You may also add several classes which have to point to different directions though, for example you would add classes 'sapUiLargeMarginEnd sapUiLargeMarginBottom' to clear a 48px space to the bottom and to the right (resp. to the left in rtl mode).

samples.name: Two-Sided Margins
samples.description: Clear the space to the left and right, top and bottom of your control. Choose a size ('Tiny', 'Small', 'Medium' or 'Large', which stands for 8px (0.5rem), 16px (1rem), 32px (2rem) or 48px (3rem) respectively) and an orientation ('BeginEnd', 'TopBottom'). If you would like to clear a 32px space to the left and right, you would add class 'sapUiMediumMarginBeginEnd'.

samples.name: Enforce Width 'auto'
samples.description: Some controls (for example the IconTabBar) do not have a 'width' property but still have a default width of 100%. We provide css class 'sapUiForceWidthAuto' to overwrite the control's width in such a case.

samples.name: Responsive Margins
samples.description: Clear the space around your control, where the margin depends on the device your are using.

samples.name: Collapsing Margins
samples.description: See how adjacent margins collapse to a single margin.

samples.name: Remove Margins
samples.description: Use our standard 'No-Margins' classes to remove existing margins from your control. You can either remove all margins at once or remove the margin on one or more sides.

samples.name: No Container Content Padding
samples.description: Many UI5 containers support the standard container content padding CSS classes. Apply the CSS class 'sapUiNoContentPadding' on a UI5 container control (e.g. Panel, IconTabBar, ...) to remove the default padding around the container content area.

samples.name: Container Content Padding
samples.description: Apply the CSS class 'sapUiContentPadding' on a UI5 container control (e.g. Page, List, Dialog, Popover, ...) to add a default padding of 1rem (16px) around the container content area.

samples.name: Responsive Container Content Padding
samples.description: Apply the CSS class 'sapUiResponsiveContentPadding' on a UI5 container control (e.g. Page, List, Dialog, Popover, ...) to add a responsive padding based on the screen size around the container content area.

samples.name: Container Content Padding and Margins
samples.description: By combining the margin and padding concepts you can flexibly design your application layout without having to write any custom CSS. This example shows a HorizontalLayout that is layouted with the standard margin and padding classes provided by UI5.
